General

General accessibility information on list boxes

Screen reader guidance

Keyboard interaction

If applicable, show how keyboard interaction might work with your component.

Use arrow keys or tab to navigate list components within a menu.

Use the space key or enter to activate a button or control within a list component.

If there are multiple items within a list that can be interacted with, space will select the list item and the user can tab within it.

Guideline.html:
Overview

The list component is a UI element that displays a list of selectable options for the user. It can contain a variety of other components like images, avatars, controls, icons, or multiple lines of text.

Resources

Lists typically fall within a Listbox Pattern, and it may be helpful to review it on W3C

Use cases

Use the menu list component to provide a list of options that the user can select, such as a navigation menu or a dropdown menu. Make sure that lists are sorted in logical ways that make the content easy to scan and identify necessary items.

In this case all menu options are using supplementary icons.

Be consistent

When using lists, present icons, text, images, controls, or actions in a consistent format.

Styles

Inset rectanble

Used when the parent container has padding; used in menu components

Inset pill

Used when the parent container has padding; used in second column and navigation items (DO NOT use in menus)

Full width

Used when the parent container has no padding

Behavior

Display

The list should be displayed when the user clicks or taps on a button or link.

Navigation

Users should be able to navigate the list using the keyboard or mouse.

Selection

When a user selects an option from the menu list, the selected option should be visually distinguished from the other options in the list.

Customization

The color, size, and typography of the menu list component can be customized to match the overall design of the application. The list items can also be customized to match the design of the application.

Avatars and button sizing

Lists can contain things like icons or avatars. The â€œ.avatar-or-image-placeholderâ€ base component can be replaced with the desired component. Standard List Item:â€¨Avatar = 32pxâ€¨Button = 32px Compact List Item

Usage of Radio, Checkbox, and Toggle in a list item.

Controls

There is a placeholder component for controls to be added. Controls can be added for greater usage of the list, or bulk actions.

Usage of Radio, Checkbox, and Toggle in a list item.

Clickable areas

The full list item is hover-able and potentially clickable as long as it does not possess buttons. If buttons are part of the list, they represent different click areas.

Various hover states of the list and components it contains.

Dos and Dontâ€™s

Use Appropriate size

Be consistent with the options you use in your list item.

Donâ€™t have multiple types of layouts for list items together.

Use the list component to create headers, if necessary.

Content

List order

Lists should be sorted in a logical manner for easy scanning and identifying. Use research, pull data, and use reasoning to define your list order.

List text length

For quick scanning, keep list items to 20-50 characters, but if necessary, list containers are also responsive and can adapt to larger strings of text.
